Cooper|date=23 February 2017|publisher=Janky Games|url=https://janky-games.com/2017/02/23/rear-view-review-the-tomorrow-children/|accessdate=2017-09-02}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=The Tomorrow Children Is an Evocative, Inscrutable Dream|author=Jack de Quidt|date=21 September 2016|publisher=VICE|url=https://www.vice.com/en_us/article/ppvkym/the-tomorrow-children-is-as-evocative-as-it-is-inscrutable-ps4|accessdate=2017-09-02}}</ref> (2016, Q-Games/Sony, PlayStation 4 Network) - Combines full control over a sculptable environment on the one hand, with the complete lack of control as an individual in a Marxist collective setting. Surrealist transformation of beings into environment by replacing animation with movement of light. *[[Everything (video game)|''Everything'']] (2017, [[David OReilly (artist)|David OReilly]], PC, PlayStation 4) - A game that allows the player to move and control any object they see in the game world, developed in an attempt to explore the philosophy of English philosopher [[Alan Watts]]. *''[[13 minutes ago]]''<ref name="eldiario">{{Cite news|url=http://www.eldiario.es/cultura/videojuegos/minutes-victima-terrorista-atentado-ETA_0_682082303.html|title=Google retira de su tienda un juego en el que eliges ser víctima o terrorista de un atentado de ETA|work=eldiario.es|access-date=2017-09-03|language=es}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.elindependiente.com/politica/2017/08/30/videojuego-eta-victima/|title=13 minutos como etarra, 13 minutos para ser víctima... en un videojuego|date=2017-08-30|work=El Independiente|access-date=2017-09-03|language=es-ES}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.eitb.eus/es/television/programas/el-programa-de-klaudio/videos/detalle/5047174/video-alain-xalabarde-creador-juego-atentado-eta/|title=Alain Xalabarde: '’13 minutes ago’ no es un juego para divertirse'|last=EiTB|website=www.eitb.eus|language=es-ES|access-date=2017-09-16}}</ref> (2017, Alain Xalabarde, Android) - A free [[interactive fiction]] that recreates the moments previous to a [[Terrorism|terrorist]] attack by Spanish group [[ETA (separatist group)|ETA]], which can be played from the perspective of the perpetrators and the victims. Google retired the game in Spain and,<ref name="eldiario" /> as of September 2017, the game could only be installed from [[Google Play]] accounts located outside of Spain. *''[[The Path of Motus]]''<ref>{{cite web|last1=Evans-Thirlwell|first1=Edwin|title=Xbox Live Indie Uprising: Sententia is an art game with a heart|url=http://www.oxm.co.uk/45722/xbox-live-indie-uprising-sententia-is-an-art-game-with-a-heart/|website=Official Xbox Magazine UK|date=4 February 2013|deadurl=bot: unknown|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130204030934/http://www.oxm.co.uk/45722/xbox-live-indie-uprising-sententia-is-an-art-game-with-a-heart/|archivedate=4 February 2013|df=}}</ref> (2018, [[Michael Hicks (game designer)|Michael Hicks]] and Gonçalo Antunes, PlayStation 4, Xbox One, PC) - A game about bullying where words have the power to destroy. *[[Bound (video game)|''Bound'']] <ref>{{cite web|title=Bound Review|url=https://www.gamespot.com/reviews/bound-review/1900-6416495/|date=18 August 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Review: Bound (Sony Playstation 4)|author=Mike S.|url=http://www.digitallydownloaded.net/2016/08/review-bound-sony-playstation-4.html|date=16 August 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Why 'Bound' went with Ballet and Modern Art|author=Steve Haske|url=https://www.inverse.com/article/19942-bound-ballet-plastic-sony-ps4-video-games|date=18 August 2016}}</ref> (2016, Santa Monica Studios, PS4, PSVR) A dancing platformer with art video elements, reflecting the story of the main character's childhood memories. *''[[Gorogoa]]'' <ref>{{cite web |url= https://www.myajc.com/technology/gorogoa-much-work-art-puzzle-game/PfftB5Ab5rI7gv5MR60ZiN/ |title= ‘Gorogoa’ is as much a work of art as it is a puzzle game |date= 22 February 2018 |accessdate=2018-06-10|first= Bell |last= Larryn |work= The Atlanta Journal-Constitution}}</ref> (2017, Jason Roberts, PS4, Xbox One, PC, Nintendo Switch, iOS) - A puzzle story presented with four images in a grid in which the player arrange, combine, and explore each image to find a connection between them in order to advance the story. The creator of ''Gorogoa'' draw by hand all the scenes<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.pcgamer.com/2012/10/11/gorogoa-indie-surreal-puzzler/ |title= Gorogoa is a completely hand-drawn puzzler of Magritte-esque surrealism |date= 11 October 2012 |accessdate=2018-06-10|first= Omri |last= Petitte |work= PC Gamer}}</ref>; he cites [[David Roberts (illustrator)|David Roberts]], [[Gustave Doré]], [[Christopher Manson]], and [[Chris Ware]] as influences to his art style.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.gamasutra.com/view/news/211040/Road_to_the_IGF_Jason_Roberts_Gorogoa/|title=Road to the IGF: Jason Roberts' Gorogoa|last=Graft|first=Kris|date=18 February 2014|accessdate=2018-06-10|work=[[Gamasutra]]}}</ref> * ''[[Where They Cremate The Roadkill]]'' (2017, PC) - An RPG styled on the Surrealist method and the philosophy of the Situationists. Story depicts the life and afterlife of a soul trapped in a world of its own creation. "Structurally anomalous, experimentally driven story and gameplay". Three art styles represent three lives, and three strands of poetic dialogue from NPCs create three major philosophies pervading the game.<ref>http://pelicanmagazine.com.au/2017/11/30/review-cremate-roadkill/</ref> <!-- Only include games that have been explicitly described by reliable sources to be "art games", and provide a reference for the source or the entry will be removed. -->

[[File:Flag of the Basque Country.svg|thumb|150x|The [[Ikurriña|Basque flag]]]] Since 1912, Spain-based association football club [[Athletic Bilbao]] have had an [[unspoken rule|unwritten rule]] whereby the club will only sign players who were born in the [[Basque Country (greater region)|Basque Country]], or who learned their football skills at a Basque club.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.athletic-club.eus/en/club.html | title = Athletic Club Official Site - Club overview including 'code'}}</ref><ref name=bbc>{{cite web|author=Phil Minshull |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/blogs/philminshull/2009/12/colour_barrier_finally_broken.html |title=Colour barrier finally broken at Athletic Bilbao |publisher=BBC |date=2009-12-16 |accessdate=2016-09-17}}</ref><ref name=cien>{{cite news|url=http://www.lavanguardia.com/deportes/futbol/20111218/54241232095/athletic-bilbao-cien-anos-sin-extranjeros.html|title=Athletic de Bilbao, cien años sin extranjeros|trans-title=Athletic Bilbao, a hundred years without foreigners|language=Spanish|newspaper=[[La Vanguardia]]|date=18 November 2011|accessdate=12 February 2018}}</ref><ref name=bbcporque>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/mundo/noticias/2012/05/120508_athletic_bilbao_fain_binda_cch.shtml|title=¿Por qué en el Athletic de Bilbao solo juegan vascos?|trans-title=Why do Athletic Bilbao play with Basques only?|publisher=[[BBC]]|website=BBC Mundo |language=Spanish|date=9 May 2012|accessdate=12 February 2018}}</ref><ref name=origin/>
The policy is related to [[Basque nationalism]]<ref name=goss /><ref name=stronghold>{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/european/welcome-to-spains-old-english-outpost-7569163.html|title=Welcome to Spain's old English outpost|last=Unwin|first=Will|newspaper=The Independent|date=15 March 2012|accessdate=20 January 2018}}</ref> and has been praised as a way to promote local talent,<ref>{{cite web|author=Pete Jenson |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/news-and-comment/pete-jenson-athletic-bilbao-s-locals-only-transfer-policy-shows-success-does-not-need-to-be-bought-9692663.html |title=Pete Jenson: Athletic Bilbao's locals-only transfer policy shows success does not need to be bought |publisher=The Independent |date=2014-08-26 |accessdate=2016-09-17}}</ref> although it has also been criticised as being discriminatory.<ref name=bbcporque/><ref name=metro>{{cite web|url=http://metro.co.uk/2013/05/31/is-athletic-bilbao-basque-only-policy-playing-by-the-rules-3823513/ |title=Is Athletic Bilbao 'Basque-only policy' playing by the rules? |work=Metro |date=2013-05-31 |accessdate=2016-09-17}}</ref>
== History == In the first decade of their existence Athletic selected English players for the team,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://inbedwithmaradona.com/retro/2012/7/4/the-history-of-athletic-bilbao-1898-1936.html|last=Radnedge|first=Keir|title=The history of Athletic Bilbao 1898–1936|magazine=[[World Soccer (magazine)|World Soccer]] (via ''In Bed With Maradona'' website)|date=1 August 1977|accessdate=21 November 2017}}</ref><ref name=cien/><ref name=origin/> but since 1912<ref name=Voluntad>{{cite web|url=http://servicios.elcorreo.com/especiales/eleccionesathletic/noticias/not270501a.html|title=Voluntad de tradición|trans-title=Will of tradition|language=Spanish|newspaper=El Correo|date=27 May 2001|accessdate=21 November 2017}}</ref> they have adhered to a policy of allowing only players born in the Basque Country or who learned their football skills at a Basque club to play for them.<ref name=bbcporque/><ref name=sk /><ref name=moyes>{{cite web|url=http://www.thenational.ae/sport/primera-liga/for-david-moyes-in-basque-derby-identity-and-sovreignty-and-points-all-part-of-the-pressure |title=For David Moyes in Basque derby, identity and sovereignty and points all part of the pressure |newspaper=[[The National (Abu Dhabi)|The National]] |date=25 September 2015 |accessdate=21 November 2017}}</ref><ref name=origin/> The motto used to describe the reasoning behind it is "Con cantera y afición, no hace falta importación" (English: "with home-grown talent and local support, you don't need foreigners").<ref name=copa>{{cite web|url=https://copa90.com/this-is-football/17208 |title=This Is Athletic Club de Bilbao |publisher=Copa90.com |date=2016-01-11 |accessdate=2016-09-17}}</ref>
[[File:Basque Country location map.png|thumb|250px|right|location of the '[[Basque Country (greater region)|Greater Basque Country]]' from which Athletic Bilbao recruits all its players]] The policy is not written into the Athletic Bilbao rulebook<ref name=bbcporque/> but has become a philosophy of the club in order to promote local players under the ''[[cantera]]'' (homegrown) system.<ref name=bbcporque/><ref name=metro /><ref name=copa /> The policy also extends to Athletic's [[Athletic Bilbao B|reserves]], their [[farm team]] [[CD Basconia]], their [[Athletic Bilbao cantera|youth teams]] and their [[Athletic Club Femenino|women's football department]].<ref name=guard>{{cite web|author=Neil Stacey |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/copa90/2016/jan/15/athletic-club-bilbao-loyalty-spain-liga-basque |title=This is Athletic Bilbao: the club whose loyalty to local talent is not negotiable |work=The Guardian |date= |accessdate=2016-09-17}}</ref> It does not apply to the coaching staff, with managers from England, Hungary, Germany, France and Argentina among those to have led the team at various times.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.athletic-club.eus/en/coaches.html |title=Coaches |publisher=Athletic Bilbao |date=|accessdate=13 February 2018 }}</ref>
They were not the only club to adhere to this approach; fellow Basque club [[Real Sociedad]] had a similar policy from the late 1960s<ref name=bbcporque/><ref name=myth/><ref name=special>{{cite web|url=http://www.espn.co.uk/football/spanish-primera-division/15/blog/post/3312276/athletic-bilbao-real-sociedad-ready-to-renew-a-special-basque-derby-rivalry|title=Athletic Bilbao, Real Sociedad ready to renew a special Basque derby rivalry|last=[[Sid Lowe|Lowe]]|first=Sid|publisher=[[ESPN]] |date=15 December 2017 |accessdate=9 November 2018}}</ref> and won two consecutive league titles in the early 1980s adhering to the self-imposed restriction<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.football-espana.net/clubs/Real%20Sociedad/history |title=Real Sociedad History|publisher=Football España |date=1 August 2017|accessdate=13 February 2018 }}</ref> (as did Athletic),<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.football-espana.net/clubs/Athletic%20Bilbao/history |title=Athletic Bilbao History |publisher=Football España |date=1 August 2017|accessdate=13 February 2018 }}</ref> but it was dropped for foreign imports in 1989 when they signed the [[Republic of Ireland national football team|Republic of Ireland]] forward [[John Aldridge]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.espnfc.co.uk/spanish-primera-division/15/blog/post/2345987/when-john-aldridge-returned-to-real-sociedad-he-got-a-heros-welcome-writes-sid-lowe |title=When John Aldridge returned to Real Sociedad, he got a hero's welcome writes Sid Lowe |publisher=[[ESPN]] |date=2015-03-13 |accessdate=2016-09-25}}</ref><ref name=carpet>{{cite web|url= https://as.com/m/diarioas/2015/03/09/english/1425923329_131050.html |title= Real Sociedad roll out the red carpet for John Aldridge |publisher=[[Diario AS]]|date=9 March 2015 |accessdate=20 July 2017}}</ref><ref name=moyes/> and for non-Basque Spanish players in 2002 with the transfer of [[Sergio Boris González|Boris]] from [[Real Oviedo]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.abc.es/hemeroteca/historico-06-08-2002/Deportes/boris-acabara-con-30-a%C3%B1os-de-tradicion-en-la-real_119558.html|title=Boris acabará con 30 años de tradición en la Real|trans-title=Boris to end 30-year tradition at Real|language=Spanish|newspaper=[[ABC (newspaper)|ABC]]|date=6 August 2002|accessdate=12 February 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.elmundo.es/elmundodeporte/2002/08/13/liga/1029227781.html|title=Boris, primer español no vasco en la Real |trans-title=Boris, first non-Basque Spaniard at Real |language=Spanish|newspaper=[[El Mundo (Spain)|El Mundo]]|date=13 August 2002|accessdate=12 February 2018}}</ref> However, the [[San Sebastián]]-based club still places a high importance on producing their own local players, and a high percentage of their squad in the 2010s were [[Real Sociedad cantera|home-grown]].<ref name=special/><ref>{{cite web|url= https://www.fourfourtwo.com/features/revealed-which-clubs-produce-most-europes-top-players |title=Revealed! Which clubs produce the most of Europe's top players?|publisher=[[FourFourTwo]] |date=1 November 2016 |accessdate=12 February 2018}}</ref>
Back in 1911, a dispute occurred between Real Sociedad and Athletic Bilbao regarding the latter fielding ineligible English players in the [[1911 Copa del Rey]];<ref name=cien/> they had also employed the services of several (non-Basque) players from [[Atlético Madrid]] which was then a branch of the Bilbao club.<ref>{{cite web | url = https://memoriasdelfutbolvasco.wordpress.com/2014/03/30/manuel-garnica/ | title = Manuel Garnica, the "Saint" who scored a goal with Athletic | trans-title =Manuel Garnica, el “Santo” que metió un gol con el Athletic |language=es|website = Memorias del Fútbol Vasco (Memories of Basque Football) | date= 30 March 2014 |accessdate = 15 October 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url =https://www.abc.es/20120508/deportes-futbol/abci-historia-athletic-atletico-201205071903.html | title = Athletic-Atlético, historia de dos parientes| trans-title= Athletic-Atlético, history of two relatives| language=es |newspaper = [[ABC (newspaper)|ABC]] | date=8 May 2012|accessdate = 10 October 2018 }}</ref> This led to the [[Royal Spanish Football Federation]] introducing a rule for the next year's competition that all players must be Spanish citizens.<ref name=origin>{{cite web|url=https://www.vavel.com/es/futbol/2017/03/11/real-sociedad/764769-athletic-el-origen-de-la-filosofia.html|title=Athletic Club: el origen de la filosofía|trans-title=Athletic Club: origin of the philosophy| language=Spanish |publisher=[[Vavel]]| date=11 March 2017|accessdate=15 October 2018}}</ref> As a large proportion of the players in that early era were Basque,<ref name=special/> relying on locals was no impediment to Athletic and they chose to maintain that approach even when the regulations were relaxed some years later.
The policy has been praised as a symbol of localised football being successful at the highest level,<ref name=bbcporque/><ref name=methods>{{cite web|url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/11096/10880323/athletic-bilbaos-methods-provide-lessons-for-premier-league-clubs|title=Athletic Bilbao's methods provide lessons for Premier League clubs|publisher=Sky Sports|date=18 May 2017|accessdate=26 December 2017}}</ref> as well as preserving a strong regional identity<ref name=stronghold/><ref name=fox>{{cite web|author=Fox Sports |url=http://www.foxsports.com/soccer/story/athletic-bilbao-club-all-basque-policy-spain-manchester-united-contrast-030812-2-030812 |title=Quaint anachronism of Athletic Bilbao's Basque nationalism |publisher=FOX Sports |date=2012-03-08 |accessdate=2016-09-17}}</ref> and being a way for Basque nationalism to be moderately expressed.<ref name=stronghold/><ref name=goss>{{cite book | first =Brian | last =Goss | title =Identity: Beyond Tradition and McWorld Neoliberalism |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=BTdQBwAAQBAJ&pg=PA98&dq=1443869074&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjXrfS_8pvPAhWkLsAKHWUIDsIQ6AEIHDAA#v=onepage&q=1443869074&f=false |publisher=Cambridge Scholars Publishing |location= | volume = | year = 2014 | isbn = 1443869074 | page =98}}</ref><ref name=fox /><ref>{{cite web|url=https://sports.vice.com/en_us/article/athletic-bilbao-is-basques-only-and-its-working|title=Athletic Bilbao is 'Basques only' and it's working |publisher=Vice |accessdate=2016-09-17}}</ref><ref name=special/> It has been described as discriminatory for only allowing Basque players to play for Athletic Bilbao,<ref name=bbcporque/><ref name=abre/><ref name=sk>{{cite web|url=http://www.sportskeeda.com/slideshow/football-5-clubs-their-unique-traditions |title=5 football clubs and their unique traditions – Slide 1 of 5 |publisher=Sportskeeda.com |date=2016-01-24 |accessdate=2016-09-17}}</ref> although it has been suggested that the policy is working for them since Athletic are one of only three clubs (along with [[Real Madrid C.F.|Real Madrid]] and [[FC Barcelona|Barcelona]]) never to have been relegated from La Liga.<ref name=stronghold/><ref name=copa /><ref name=guard/>
==Origins of players== ===Ethnic minorities=== [[File:3 de diciembre 2015 Bienvenida al Atlethic de Bilbao 11 (23388774212) (cropped).jpg|thumb|left|130px|[[Iñaki Williams]], of [[West Africa]]n origin but born and raised in the Basque region]] Due to a relatively low immigrant population in the region,<ref name=bbcporque/><ref>{{cite news |url=http://especial.elcorreo.com/2017/extranjeros-euskadi/|title=El origen de los extranjeros que viven en el País Vasco|trans-title=The origin of foreigners living in the Basque Country |language=Spanish|publisher=[[El Correo]] |date=1 January 2017 |accessdate=11 June 2017}}</ref><ref name=abre>{{cite news|url=https://www.elcorreo.com/vizcaya/20080323/deportes/athletic/athletic-abre-mundo-20080323.html|title=El Athletic se abre al mundo|trans-title=Athletic opens up to the world|language=Spanish|newspaper=El Correo |date=23 March 2008|accessdate=4 October 2018}}</ref> the policy also had the consequence of Athletic Bilbao being the last club in [[La Liga]] to have never fielded a black player. That was ended in 2011 when [[Jonas Ramalho]], whose father is [[Angola]]n, made his debut.<ref name=bbcporque/><ref name=cien/><ref name=myth>[https://www.si.com/more-sports/2011/11/23/jonas Jonas Ramalho helping to dispel longstanding Athletic Bilbao myth]; ''[[Sports Illustrated]]'', 23 November 2011</ref> In 2015 [[Iñaki Williams]] (born in Bilbao to [[Immigration to Spain|Liberian immigrant]] parents) became Athletic's first black goalscorer.<ref name=methods/><ref>[http://www.skysports.com/football/news/11827/9723739/inaki-williams-becomes-first-black-athletic-bilbao-goalscorer-in-117-year-history Inaki Williams becomes first black Athletic Bilbao goalscorer in 117-year history]; [[Sky Sports]], 20 February 2015</ref> Prior to Ramalho, in 2000 the first African-born player in the club's youth system was Blanchard Moussayou<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.athletic-club.eus/en/players/1198/blanchard-mooussayou-sambou.html|title=Blanchard Mooussayou Sambou|publisher=Athletic Bilbao|accessdate=11 February 2018}}</ref> whose promising career was curtailed by injury; some years later, he stated his belief that it was 'twice as hard' for a black player to make an impact at the club.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://bizkaia.eldesmarque.com/athletic-club/noticias/28239-blanchard-q|title=Blanchard: "El jugador negro tiene aquí doble dificultad" |trans-title=Blanchard: "The black player has double difficulty here"|language=Spanish|newspaper=El Desmarque|date=22 November 2011|accessdate=12 February 2018}}</ref>
Former academy trainee [[Yuri Berchiche]], who rejoined Athletic in the summer of 2018 as one of the club's most expensive signings,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.marca.com/en/football/spanish-football/2018/07/02/5b3a066ae5fdea43378b4650.html|title=Athletic Club seal four-year Yuri Berchiche deal|newspaper=Marca|date=2 July 2018|accessdate=30 September 2018}}</ref> has an Algerian father but showed no interest in playing for [[Algeria national football team|their national team]] when the matter was put to him.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.algerie-focus.com/2017/12/football-yuri-berchiche-balaie-possibilite-de-defendre-couleurs-de-lalgerie/|title=Football / Yuri Berchiche balaie la possibilité de défendre les couleurs de l'Algérie|trans-title=Football / Yuri Berchiche sweeps the possibility of defending the colours of Algeria|publisher=Algérie Focus|language=fr|date=10 December 2017|accessdate=30 September 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://observalgerie.com/actualite-algerie/sport/equipe-nationale-yuri-berchiche-dit-non-a-lalgerie/|title= Équipe nationale : Yuri Berchiche dit non à l'Algérie|trans-title=National team: Yuri Berchiche says no to Algeria|publisher=ObservAlgerie|language=fr|date=16 April 2018|accessdate=30 September 2018}}</ref>
As of 2018, Athletic's academy teams include a small number of players of an ethnic minority (mostly [[Afro-Spaniard]]) background, including Cameroon-born goalkeeper [[Chris Atangana]],<ref>{{cite news |url=https://as.com/futbol/2017/11/14/primera/1510687840_265078.html |title=Atangana surge entre los sucesores de Arrizabalaga |trans-title=Atangana emerges among the successors of Arrizabalaga |language=Spanish|publisher=Diario AS |date=14 November 2017 |accessdate=3 February 2018 }}</ref> forward Nico Williams (the younger brother of Iñaki),<ref>{{cite news |url=http://bizkaia.eldesmarque.com/athletic-club/noticias/63256-nico-sigue-la-estela-de-inaki-williams |title=Nico sigue la estela de Iñaki Williams |trans-title=Nico follows in the wake of Iñaki Williams |language=Spanish|publisher=El Desmarque |date=12 October 2017 |accessdate=3 February 2018 }}</ref> and defender Loic Boum, also of [[Cameroon]]ian origin, who having been orphaned as a child was a ward of the [[Government of Navarre]] when he moved to the club in 2014.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://athletic.elcorreo.com/noticias/201406/04/lezama-pide-permiso-gobierno-20140604171608.html|title=El Athletic, a por un infantil camerunés de Osasuna |trans-title=Athletic, in for a Cameroonian child from Osasuna |language=Spanish|publisher=El Correo |date=5 June 2014 |accessdate=3 February 2018 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.lacanteradelezama.com/loic-boum-es-ya-nuevo-jugador-del-athletic/ |title=Loic Boum es ya nuevo jugador del Athletic |trans-title=Loic Boum is now a new Athletic player |language=Spanish|publisher=La Cantera de Lezama |date=4 August 2014 |accessdate=3 February 2018 }}</ref>
===French players=== The club also rarely fielded players from the French [[Northern Basque Country]], with [[Bixente Lizarazu]] being the first French Basque to play for the club in 1996<ref name=cien/><ref name=myth/><ref name=Voluntad/> and [[Aymeric Laporte]] the first to successfully graduate from the [[youth system]] in 2012.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/these-football-times/2014/dec/08/french-basque-country-rugby-heartland-deschamps-lizarazu |title=The French Basque Country: a rugby heartland with world-class footballers |work=The Guardian |date= |accessdate=2016-09-17}}</ref><ref name=moyes/>
Laporte's signing in 2009 prompted debate regarding the definitions of the policy, as he had no link to the Basque region through birth or residency, and a blood link only via [[Grandparent#Great-grandparents|great-grandparents]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://bizkaia.eldesmarque.com/athletic-club/noticias/36668-laporte-tengo-sangre-vasca-por-parte-de-mis-bisabuelos |title=Laporte: "Tengo sangre vasca por parte de mis bisabuelos" |trans-title=Laporte: "I have Basque blood through my great-grandparents" |publisher=El Desmarque |language=Spanish|date=25 July 2013 |accessdate=11 June 2017}}</ref><ref name=among>{{cite web |url=http://onlyfootball.fr/?p=513 |title=Aymeric Laporte, un Basque parmi les Basques |trans-title=Aymeric Laporte, a Basque among the Basques |publisher=Only Football |language=French|date=14 May 2013 |accessdate=11 June 2017}}</ref><ref name=butterflies>{{cite web |url=http://www.sofoot.com/aymeric-laporte-a-arrete-de-regarder-les-papillons-173450.html |title=Aymeric Laporte a "arrêté de regarder les papillons" |trans-title=Aymeric Laporte "stopped watching the butterflies” |publisher=So Foot |language=French |date=26 September 2013|accessdate=11 June 2017}}</ref><ref name=moyes/> He did join a team in the territory, [[Aviron Bayonnais FC|Aviron Bayonnais]],<ref name=ownbio>{{cite web |url=http://www.aymericlaporte.com/en/bio/|title=Biography - Athletic Bilbao signing and beginnings|trans-title=|work=Aymeric Laporte official website |date=|accessdate=11 June 2017}}</ref><ref name=butterflies/> but only by arrangement after the initial approach from Athletic, as he was too young to move to a club outside France at the time – he arrived formally in 2010.<ref name=methods/>
{{ill|Yanis Rahmani|eu}}, a [[Algerians in France|Frenchman of Algerian origin]] raised in [[Sestao]],<ref name=abre/> progressed as far as Basconia at the same time as Laporte but did not turn professional with the club.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://mirandes.elcorreo.com/noticias/201706/27/extremo-zurdo-yanis-rahmani-20170626234606.html |title=El extremo zurdo Yanis Rahmani se incorpora al Mirandés para las dos próximas temporadas |trans-title=The left winger Yanis Rahmani joins the Mirandés for the next two seasons|language=Spanish|newspaper =El Correo|date=27 June 2017|accessdate=3 February 2018}}</ref>
====Griezmann debate==== [[Antoine Griezmann]], the French forward developed by Real Sociedad, was the subject of debate regarding his eligibility for a theoretical move to Athletic as he emerged as an elite player in 2012.<ref name=impossible/> Hailing from [[Bourgogne-Franche-Comté|Burgundy]], he arrived at the San Sebastián club aged 14<ref name=antoine>{{cite web|url=https://www.fourfourtwo.com/news/griezmann-not-interested-bilbao-speculation|title=Griezmann not interested in Bilbao speculation|publisher=FourFourTwo|date=5 September 2013|accessdate=20 January 2018}}</ref> but only to play football for their academy teams rather than for some other non-sporting reason, and has no connection to the French Basque Country other than attending school there after signing for Real.
The opinions of some (including Athletic's academy director [[José María Amorrortu]]) <ref name=impossible>{{cite web|url=http://www.marca.com/en/football/spanish-football/2017/01/19/5880a91522601d4a498b4577.html |title=Athletic Club's impossible dream of signing Griezmann |newspaper=Marca|date=19 January 2017|accessdate=3 February 2018}}</ref> were that his training at a Basque club from a young age adhered to the policy,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eitb.eus/es/deportes/futbol/athletic/detalle/900544/el-athletic-interesado-antoine-griezmann--real-sociedad/|title=¿Puede fichar el Athletic a Griezmann?|trans-title=Can Athletic sign Griezmann?|language=Spanish|publisher=EITB|date=6 June 2012|accessdate=20 January 2018}}</ref> while others insisted that he had the same (ineligible) status as any adult player transferred in by Real and the other local professional clubs.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.goal.com/es/news/4194/editoriales/2012/09/28/3407931/antoine-griezmann-no-entra-en-la-filosof%C3%ADa-del-athletic-de|title=Antoine Griezmann no entra en la filosofía del Athletic de Bilbao|trans-title=Antoine Griezmann does not enter the philosophy of Athletic Bilbao|language=Spanish|publisher=Goal|date=28 September 2012|accessdate=20 January 2018}}</ref>
In any event, Griezmann showed little interest in joining Athletic,<ref name=antoine/> subsequently moved on to [[Atlético Madrid]]<ref name=impossible/> and was voted the [[2016 Ballon d'Or|world's third best player]] in 2016,<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/dec/12/cristiano-ronaldo-ballon-dor-fourth-lionel-messi|title=Cristiano Ronaldo wins Ballon d’Or for the fourth time|date=12 December 2016|newspaper=The Guardian|accessdate=20 January 2018}}</ref> making any move to Bilbao unlikely in the medium term. In respect of any future players of a similar trajectory, Athletic's position on recruitment remains unconfirmed.
===Players of Basque descent=== [[File:Fernando Amorebieta.png|thumb|right|120px|[[Fernando Amorebieta]], born in Venezuela but raised in the Basque Country]] In 1980 the club was believed to have given serious consideration to signing [[Iker Zubizarreta]], a young [[Venezuelan people|Venezuelan]] of Basque heritage (his grandfather [[Félix Zubizarreta|Félix]] had starred for Athletic in the 1910s) who had impressed at the [[Football at the 1980 Summer Olympics|football tournament]] at the [[1980 Summer Olympics]], but decided not to pursue it.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.naiz.eus/en/hemeroteca/gara/editions/2015-08-06/hemeroteca_articles/iker-zubizarreta-el-nieto-de-leon-que-pudo-ser-cachorro|title=Iker Zubizarreta: el nieto de león que pudo ser cachorro |trans-title=Iker Zubizarreta: grandson of a lion who could have been a puppy|language=Spanish|publisher=[[Gara]]|date=6 August 2015|accessdate=11 June 2017}}</ref>
In 2011, media sources claimed that Athletic had shown interest in young [[Mexican people|Mexican]] midfielder [[Jonathan Espericueta]]<ref>{{cite news |url=http://futbol.as.com/futbol/2011/06/26/mas_futbol/1309069655_850215.html |title=Interés por el mexicano Espericueta|trans-title=Interest in the Mexican Espericueta |language=Spanish |publisher=[[Diario AS]] |date=26 June 2011 |accessdate=11 June 2017}}</ref> but no such move materialised, and the player himself (who did later play in Spain with [[Villarreal CF B|Villarreal B]]) stated that his Basque connection was as distant as a great-great-grandfather.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.elnuevoheraldo.com/deportes/le-dice-no-a-europa/article_2016b80d-0ccd-5b95-864d-f60cca06d84c.html |title=Le dice 'no' a Europa |trans-title=He says "no" to Europe |language=Spanish |publisher=[[El Nuevo Heraldo]] |date=23 June 2011 |accessdate=11 June 2017}}</ref>
The [[Uruguay national football team|Uruguayan international]] [[Diego Forlán]], whose paternal grandmother was Basque, claimed he had talks over a potential transfer to the club in 2004<ref>{{cite news|title=Forlán afirma que negoció su fichaje por el Athletic|trans-title=Forlán confirms that he negotiated a transfer to Athletic|url=http://athletic.elcorreo.com/noticias/2010-09-14/forlan-hubo-contactos-athletic-201009141353.html|accessdate=18 March 2017|work=[[El Correo]] |date=14 September 2010|language=Spanish}}</ref> but this signing would have been incompatible with the club's current policy as Forlan was not born in a Basque region, nor did he play football as a youth (or at any point in his career) at a club in the territory. That is also true of [[Argentinian people|Argentinian]] forward [[Gonzalo Higuaín]],<ref>{{cite news|url=http://archivo.marca.com/edicion/marca/futbol/1a_division/athletic/es/desarrollo/661629.html|title=La sorpresa de Lamikiz podría ser un extremo argentino de River Plate|trans-title=The surprise of Lamikiz could be an Argentine winger from River Plate|language=Spanish|newspaper=Marca|date=21 June 2006|accessdate=20 January 2018}}</ref> and Spaniards [[Benjamín Zarandona]],<ref name=myth/><ref name=bbcporque/> [[Kepa Blanco]]<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.elcorreo.com/vizcaya/20070628/deportes/athletic/macua-prefiere-cerrar-nido-20070628.html|title=Macua prefiere cerrar con Del Nido la compra de Kepa antes de negociar con el jugador|trans-title=Macua prefers to conclude the purchase of Kepa with Del Nido before negotiating with the player|language=Spanish|newspaper=El news|url=http://www.elcorreo.com/vizcaya/20070630/deportes/athletic/evidente-macua-debia-marcha-20070630.html|title=El Athletic vuelve a pensar en Jorge López|trans-title=Athletic thinks again about Jorge López|language=Spanish|newspaper=Marca|date=30 June 2007|accessdate=20 January 2018}}</ref> all players with tenuous Basque links who were also said to have been considered as potential signings by the club's presidential candidates when Athletic were [[History of Athletic Bilbao#The "black biennium"|struggling on the field]] under the restrictions of the policy.<ref>{{cite Culture and Society in Spain: An Ethnography of Basque Fandom|last=Vaczi|first=Mariann |ISBN=9781317677307|year=2015|publisher=[[Routledge]]}}</ref> in 2015 the [[Australian people|Australian]] winger [[Tommy Oar]] (with Basque-born grandparents) was the subject of similar speculation.<ref>{{cite web|title=Oar reveals: I almost joined Bilbao|url=http://www.socceroos.com.au/article/oar-reveals-i-almost-joined-bilbao/x17v90j1ets1lpjkxy2corp8|website=socceroos.com.au|publisher=Football Federation Australia|date=18 August 2015|accessdate=3 February 2018}}</ref> Multiple [[UEFA Champions League]] winner [[Marco Asensio]]'s Basque father, a former footballer, suggested his son to Athletic as a potential signing early in his career, only to be informed that [[Mallorca]]-born Marco did not fit the philosophy.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://en.as.com/en/2016/10/22/football/1477131768_167624.html|title=Asensio's father dreamed his son would play for Athletic Club|newspaper=Diario AS|date=22 October 2016|accessdate=15 October 2018}}</ref>
This contrasts with players who were signed by the club such as [[Higinio Ortúzar]],<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.martiperarnau.com/higinio-ortuzar-el-chileno-de-sangre-vasca/|title=Higinio Ortúzar: el chileno de sangre vasca |trans-title=Higinio Ortúzar: the Chilean with Basque blood|language=Spanish|publisher=|website=Club Perarnau - The Tactical Room|newspaper=|date=13 November 2014|accessdate=11 December 2017}}</ref> [[Vicente Biurrun]],<ref name=cien/> [[Javier Iturriaga]]<ref name=zarautz>{{cite news|url=http://www.diariovasco.com/prensa/20061019/costaurola/zarautz-javier-iturriaga-debuto_20061019.html |title=Zarautz: Javier Iturriaga debutó con el Athletic de Bilbao |trans-title=Zarautz: of the Bilbao defence |language=es |work=[[El Mundo (Spain)|El Mundo]] |date=29 January 2017 |accessdate=23 November 2018 }}</ref> [[Armando Merodio]],<ref name=fronton>{{cite news|url=https://elpais.com/diario/1983/04/03/deportes/418168808_850215.html|title=Sarabia, la figura del actual Athlétic de Bilbao|trans-title=Sarabia, the figurehead of today's Athlétic |url=https://elpais.com/diario/2008/02/01/opinion/1201820403_850215.html|title=¿Habrá un 'lehendakari' negro?|trans-title=|language=Spanish|newspaper=[[El País]]|date=1 February 2008|accessdate=12 being born in [[Zaragoza]] as his upbringing was almost entirely in the Basque region.<ref name=VavelGL>{{cite web|url=https://www.vavel.com/es/futbol/2016/11/30/segunda-division-b-grupo-2/727308.html|title=Entrevista. Gorka Luariz: “ Cuando llegué a Zamudio dije que haría 10 goles como mínimo|trans-title=Interview. Gorka Luariz: "When I got to Zamudio I said I would make 10 goals at least"|language=es |work=[[Vavel]] |date=30 November 2016|accessdate=7 November 2018}}</ref>
[[File:Rrios2013002.jpg|thumb|left|120px|[[Roberto Ríos]], born in Bilbao but raised and trained in [[Seville]]]] Conversely, players born in the Basque Country but raised elsewhere are considered eligible.<ref name=myth/> [[Fernando Llorente]] was born in Pamplona<ref name=oyon/> but lived his whole childhood in [[Rincón de Soto]] (close to Basque territory but outside it) before he was recruited as an 11-year-old.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://hemeroteca.elmundodeportivo.es/preview/2005/01/18/pagina-24/1532732/pdf.html|title=Fue todo tan rápido que ni me lo creía|trans-title=Everything was so fast I could not believe it|newspaper=[[Mundo Deportivo]]|language=Spanish|date=18 January 2005|accessdate=11 June 2017}}</ref> Two of Athletic's most expensive signings, the Bilbao-born [[Spain national football team|Spain internationals]] [[Roberto Ríos]]<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.elmundo.es/1997/07/20/deportes/20N0074.html|title=Ríos y el Athletic pasan a la historia|trans-title=Ríos and Athletic make history|language=Spanish|publisher=[[El Mundo (Spain)|El Mundo]]|date=20 July 1997|accessdate=11 June 2017}}</ref> and [[Ander Herrera]]<ref>{{cite news |url=http://soccernet.espn.go.com/news/story/_/id/877509/athletic-bilbao-confirm-deal-to-sign-ander-herrera?cc=5739 |title=Athletic confirm Herrera deal|publisher=[[ESPN]]|date=7 February 2011|accessdate=11 June 2017}}</ref> learned their skills in the cities where their footballing fathers were based professionally ([[Eusebio Ríos|Eusebio]] at [[Real Betis]] of [[Seville]], and [[Pedro María Herrera|Pedro]] at [[Real Zaragoza]] respectively); [[Gaizka Mendieta]] (son of [[Andrés Mendieta]] of [[CD Castellón]]) had similar origins but turned down a move,<ref name=pain>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2003/aug/24/sport.comment2|title=Leaving the pain in Spain |publisher=[[The Guardian]]|date=24 August 2003|accessdate=11 June 2017}}</ref> albeit he remained a proud Basque who played for the [[Basque Country national football team|unofficial representative team]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eff-fvf.eus/pub/verFichaPartido.asp?idioma=ca&idPartido=139|title=Euskadi 5–1 Nigeria| publisher=[[Basque Country national football team|Euskadiko Futbol Federakundea]]| language=Spanish|date=29 November 1999|accessdate=11 June 2017}}</ref>
In the years prior to the [[Spanish Civil War]], Athletic undertook a project named 'Operation Return', seeking players born in the Basque region who had emigrated to other countries. One of the few who actually made a competitive appearance for the club was [[:es:Nemesio Tamayo|Nemesio Tamayo]] who had begun his career in his adopted homeland of Chile and also played in Mexico before a brief spell in his birthplace.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://jonrivas7.wixsite.com/athletic/single-post/2016/1/17/Tamayo-el-primero-de-la-Operaci%C3%B3n-Retorno |title=La Operación Retorno de 1934 |trans-title=The Operation Return of 1934 |work=El Mundo |language=es |via=Historia Rojiblancas |date=17 January 2016 |accessdate=23 November 2018 }}</ref> The arrival of Bilbao-born [[Emilio Aldecoa]] in 1947 was unusual as he had spent the past decade of his life in England, having been evacuated as a teenage refugee of the Civil War.<ref>{{cite web|title=A Spanish refugee boy 78 years ago blazed the trail for David Silva and Cesc Fabregas |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/news-and-comment/a-spanish-refugee-boy-78-years-ago-blazed-the-trail-for-david-silva-and-cesc-fabregas-10488958.html |newspaper=[[The Independent]] |date=6 September 2015|accessdate=12 June 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=First foreign footballers: Spain’s Emilio Aldecoa|url=https://www.football365.com/news/first-foreign-footballers-spains-emilio-aldecoa |website=Football365|date=16 March 2018|accessdate=12 June 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Into the ether: When football welcomed refugees|url=https://www.amnesty.org.uk/blogs/ether/when-football-welcomed-refugees |publisher=[[Amnesty International]] |date=26 April 2017|accessdate=12 June 2018}}</ref> Another member of that refugee group was the club's star goalkeeper of the era [[Raimundo Pérez Lezama]], although he had returned home much sooner on the outbreak of [[World War II]]; a third Basque refugee [[Sabino Barinaga]] turned down an offer from Athletic and joined [[Real Madrid C.F.|Real Madrid]].<ref>{{cite web|title=El momento histórico|trans-title=The historic moment|url=http://algomasquefutbol.blogspot.pt/2007/02/el-momento-histrico.html||website=Algo Más que Fútbol|date=6 February 2007|accessdate=12 June 2018}}</ref>
===Players from Biscay=== It was once the case that Athletic would usually recruit from the [[Biscay]] province surrounding [[Bilbao]]<ref name=myth/> while the other leading clubs Real Sociedad and [[CA Osasuna|Osasuna]] would focus on players from their respective provinces [[Gipuzkoa]] and [[Navarre]]. In recent decades (with the pool of potential players declining due to a low birth rate in the area),<ref name=lehendakari/> Athletic expanded their recruitment in these other areas in their efforts to accommodate the best players with any Basque links. This saw many talented players from [[San Sebastián]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://real-sociedad.diariovasco.com/noticias/201610/13/hasta-trece-transfugas-defendido-20161013005246-v.html|title=Real Sociedad: Hasta trece tránsfugas han defendido las dos camisetas|trans-title=Up to thirteen 'traitors' have defended the two shirts|newspaper=[[El Diario Vasco]]|language=Spanish|date=13 October 2016|accessdate=12 February 2018}}</ref> and [[Pamplona]]<ref>{{cite news |url=http://real-sociedad.diariovasco.com/noticias/2011-02-10/chantrea-mejor-vivero-athletic-20110210.html |title=La Chantrea, el mejor vivero, es del Athletic |trans-title=Chantrea, Athletic's best nursery |language=Spanish |publisher=[[El Diario Vasco]]|date= 10 February 2011 |accessdate=12 February 2018}}</ref> join the club, and also caused Real Sociedad to abandon their own Basque policy in the face of the competition for signings.<ref name=morboreview>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2001/mar/26/newsstory.sport13|title=Morbo: The Story of Spanish Football by Phil Ball (London: WSC Books, 2001)|date=26 March 2001|accessdate=15 November 2017|work=[[The Guardian]]|last=[[Sid Lowe|Lowe]]|first=Sid}}</ref><ref name=moyes/>
Transfers between the clubs [[Basque football derbies#Osasuna and Navarre|increased tensions with Osasuna]]<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.marca.com/futbol/athletic/2017/07/07/595fd8d6ca4741a12c8b4646.html|title=Areso, último capítulo del trasvase Osasuna-Athletic|trans-title=Areso, latest chapter of the Osasuna-Athletic transfers|language=Spanish|newspaper=Marca|date=7 July 2017|accessdate=12 February 2018}}</ref><ref name=peligro>{{cite web|url=https://www.vavel.com/es/futbol/2018/02/06/osasuna/876373-tajonar-y-el-eterno-peligro.amp.html|title=Tajonar y el eterno peligro|trans-title=Tajonar and the eternal danger|language=Spanish|publisher=[[Vavel]] |date=6 February 2018 |accessdate=11 November 2018}}</ref> and with Real;<ref name=morboreview/> Athletic paid over the odds for players from those rivals on several occasions, including breaking the national record for a native player for [[Lorenzo Juarros García|Loren]] in 1989,<ref name=pagado>{{cite news|url=http://athletic.elcorreo.com/noticias/2010-12-01/athletic-pagado-casi-millones-20101201.html|title=El Athletic ha pagado casi 15 millones a la Real en 21 años|trans-title=Athletic has paid almost 15 million to Real in 21 years|language=Spanish|newspaper=El Correo|date=1 December 2010|accessdate=19 June 2018}}</ref> setting further records for purchasing a teenager with [[Joseba Etxeberria]] in 1995<ref>{{cite news|url=https://elpais.com/diario/1995/07/07/ultima/805068001_850215.html|title=550 millones por un juvenil: Athletic paga por Etxeberria un traspaso récord por un español|trans-title=550 million for a youth: Athletic pays a record transfer for a Spaniard for Etxeberria|language=Spanish|newspaper=El País|date=7 July 1995|accessdate=19 June 2018}}</ref> followed by the €6 million outlay on the untested [[Javi Martínez]] in 2006,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://msnsport.skysports.com/story/0,19528,11840_2382346,00.html|title=Athletic spend big on starlet|publisher=[[Sky Sports]]|date=2 July 2006|accessdate=19 June 2018|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100403223700/http://msnsport.skysports.com/story/0%2C19528%2C11840_2382346%2C00.html|archivedate=3 April 2010|df=}}</ref> being ordered by courts to pay €5 million for [[Iban Zubiaurre]] in 2008 after his signing was found to be a breach of contract,<ref>{{cite web|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20051122163418/http://www.uefa.com/competitions/intertotocup/news/kind=1/newsid=313559.html|archive-date=22 November 2005|url=http://www.uefa.com/competitions/intertotocup/news/kind=1/newsid=313559.html |title=Zubiaurre gets Athletic chance|publisher=[[UEFA]] |date=1 July 2005|accessdate=19 June 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://as.com/futbol/2005/07/02/mas_futbol/1120285630_850215.html|title=El Athletic presentó ayer a Zubiaurre y la Real estalla|trans-title=Athletic presented Zubiaurre yesterday and Real explodes |publisher=Diario AS|language=Spanish|date=2 July 2005|accessdate=19 June 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.elmundo.es/elmundodeporte/2008/06/04/futbol/1212582939.html |title=El Athletic tendrá que pagar cinco millones a la Real por Zubiaurre |trans-title=Athletic to pay Real Sociedad €5 millions for Zubiaurre |publisher=[[El Mundo (Spain)|El Mundo]]|language=Spanish|date=5 June 2008|accessdate=19 June 2018}}</ref> and meeting [[Iñigo Martínez]]'s €32 million [[release clause]] in 2018<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.athletic-club.eus/en/news/18697/inigo-martinez-jokalaria-fitxatu-du-athletic-clubek.html|title=Iñigo Martínez signing|publisher=Athletic Bilbao|date=30 January 2018|accessdate=19 June 2018 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.goal.com/en/news/athletic-bilbao-sign-martinez-from-real-sociedad/g2qcqw6nfa8t1fj74qrh862fb|title=Athletic Bilbao sign Inigo Martinez to replace Aymeric Laporte|publisher=Goal.com|date=30 January 2018|accessdate=19 June 2018 }}</ref> (offset by losing Aymeric Laporte the same day in a similar deal worth double that amount).<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/42873612|title=Aymeric Laporte: Manchester City sign French defender for club-record £57m|publisher=[[BBC Sport]]|date=30 January 2018|accessdate=19 June 2018 }}</ref>
That change of focus also led to fewer players from the home province being selected; in a 2011 fixture, none of the Athletic starters or substitutes were from Biscay.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.footballwhispers.com/blog/athletic-bilbaos-transfer-policy| title = Football Whispers – Athletic Bilbao’s transfer policy}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.athletic-club.eus/en/match-statistics/1_4456/2010-11_real-zaragoza_athletic-club.html| title = Real Zaragoza 2 Athletic Club 1 02/03/2011|publisher=Athletic Bilbao|accessdate=11 June 2017}}</ref> However, in subsequent years more local players made the grade, and the situation appears unlikely to occur again in the near future – twelve of the 25 players in the [[2016–17 Athletic Bilbao season#Squad|2016–17 squad]] were born in Biscay, and in November 2017 a study showed that 77% of players in the academy teams hailed from the province.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://bizkaia.eldesmarque.com/athletic-club/noticias/64416-el-77-de-canteranos-del-athletic-son-vizcainos|title=El 77% de canteranos del Athletic son vizcaínos|trans-title=77% of Athletic homegrown players are from Biscay|language=Spanish|newspaper=El Desmarque|date=27 November 2017|accessdate=26 December 2017}}</ref>
===Players from outside the region=== On the other hand, the definitions of the philosophy are stretched occasionally to accommodate promising youngsters with little Basque connection, which does not always sit well with some of the club's followers.
[[Enric Saborit]], originally from [[Catalonia]], who graduated through the youth and reserve levels to reach the first team, caused questions to be asked when he signed in 2008; he had no connection with the region by birth or blood, but while already 16 years old and playing in [[RCD Espanyol]]'s ''cantera'' teams, he moved to [[Vitoria-Gasteiz]] where his mother had relocated for work two years earlier. As soon as he became a resident of the territory, Saborit was deemed eligible by Athletic to play for the club.<ref name=debate>{{cite news |url=http://archivo.marca.com/edicion/marca/futbol/1a_division/athletic/es/desarrollo/1094438.html |title=Saborit abre el debate de la filosofía del club |trans-title=Saborit opens debate on club philosophy |publisher=[[Marca (newspaper)|Marca]]|language=Spanish|date=27 February 2008 |accessdate=11 June 2017}}</ref><ref name=abre/><ref name=catalan>{{cite news |url=http://www.lavanguardia.com/deportes/futbol/20170104/413083135665/saborit-catalan-athletic.html |title=Saborit, un catalán en el Athletic |trans-title=Saborit, a Catalan at Athletic|publisher=[[La Vanguardia]]|language=Spanish|date=5 January 2017 |accessdate=11 June 2017}}</ref>
In summer 2017, Athletic recruited Youssouf Diarra, an 18-year-old forward born in Mali who was raised in Catalonia and had spent the past two years playing for clubs in Navarre after moving these to continue his education, which the club deemed sufficient under the policy.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lacanteradelezama.com/youssouf-diarra-se-incorporara-al-basconia/|title=Youssouf Diarra se incorporará al Basconia |trans-title=Youssouf Diarra to join Basconia|publisher=La Cantera De Lezama|language=Spanish|date=24 June 2017|accessdate=4 August 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://as.com/futbol/2017/02/03/primera/1486092170_940650.amp.html |title=La prueba del malí Diarra pone en marcha el debate filosófico |trans-title=The trial of Malian Diarra launches a philosophical debate |newspaper=Diario AS|language=Spanish|date=3 February 2017|accessdate=30 September 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://bizkaia.eldesmarque.com/athletic-club/noticias/61585-ander-alana-si-diarra-esta-aqui-entra-en-la-filosofia|title=Ander Alaña: "Si Diarra está aquí entra en la filosofía"|trans-title=Ander Alaña: "If Diarra is here he enters the philosophy"|publisher=El Desmarque|language=Spanish|date=23 July 2017|accessdate=4 August 2017}}</ref> The previous year they had signed 16-year-old Colombia-born defender Deiby Ochoa, who lived in [[La Rioja (Spain)|La Rioja]] and had only ever played for clubs in that region.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lacanteradelezama.com/el-juvenil-deiby-ochoa-nuevo-fichaje-desde-el-comillas-cf/|title=El juvenil Deiby Ochoa nuevo fichaje desde el Comillas CF|trans-title=The junior Deiby Ochia is a new signing from Comillas CF|publisher=La Cantera De Lezama|language=Spanish|date=16 June 2016|accessdate=4 August 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.orain.eus/el-athletic-hace-saltar-por-los-aires-su-centenaria-filosofia-trayendo-a-lezama-a-jovenes-de-fuera-de-euskal-herria/|title=El Athletic hace saltar por los aires su centenaria filosofia trayendo a Lezama a jovenes de fuera de Euskal Herria|trans-title=Athletic throws out their century-old philosophy bringing youngsters to Lezama from outside the Basque Country|publisher=Orain.eus|language=Spanish|date=22 June 2016|accessdate=4 August 2017}}</ref> Both players had attended trial matches at the [[Lezama Facilities|Lezama]] training centre.
However, despite having invited Ochoa (the spelling of whose name was changed to the Basque ''Otxoa'' in club records) to join,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.athletic-club.eus/en/players/2549/otxoa.html|title=Deiby Otxoa profile|publisher=Athletic Bilbao|accessdate=26 December 2017}}</ref> in October 2017 it was announced that Athletic's youth training camp in [[Oyón-Oion|Oion]] – a village in [[Álava]], but just a few miles from [[Logroño]] – would no longer accept players who did not fit the Athletic philosophy, effectively excluding around 150 Riojan youngsters of various ages from the system and leaving only around ten Basques across the squads.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.lavanguardia.com/deportes/futbol/20171021/432229155688/athletic-oyon-la-rioja.html|title=El Athletic expulsa a 150 canteranos por su procedencia riojana|trans-title=Athletic expels 150 canteranos for their Riojan origin|language=Spanish|newspaper=La Vanguardia|date=21 October 2017|accessdate=26 December 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://athletic.elcorreo.com/athletic-expulsa-cantera-20171021223007-nt.html|title=El Athletic no admitirá a niños riojanos en su escuela alavesa de Oion|trans-title=Athletic will not admit children from La Rioja in their Alavese school at Oion|language=Spanish|newspaper=El Correo|date=21 October 2017|accessdate=26 December 2017}}</ref><ref name=oyon/> Past recruits born in that region, who were considered eligible due to their formative club being Osasuna or Real Sociedad, include [[José Mari García]], [[Santiago Ezquerro]], [[David López (footballer, born 1982)|David López]] and [[Borja Viguera]]; however, the justifications for allowing [[Luis de la Fuente Castillo|Luis de la Fuente]] and later [[Daniel Aranzubia]] to join Athletic's youth system directly from Riojan clubs were less clear.<ref name=oyon>{{Cite news|url=https://www.larioja.com/deportes/futbol/llorente-haber-oyon-20171020002918-ntvo.html|title=Llorente sí podría haber ido a Oyón |trans-title=Llorente could have gone to Oyón|newspaper=La Rioja|date=26 October 2017 |accessdate=29 November 2018|language=Spanish}}</ref>
In January 2018, Athletic announced a new signing who was more obviously non-Basque by ethnicity: 25-year-old [[Cristian Ganea]], a [[Romania national football team|Romanian international]]<ref name="Athletic_Bilbao_transfer">{{cite web|url=http://www.athletic-club.eus/en/news/18649/cristian-ganea-initial-agreement-with-fc-viitorul.html|title=Cristian Ganea: Initial agreement with FC Viitorul|publisher=Athletic Bilbao|date=15 January 2018|accessdate=16 January 2018}}</ref> who was also born in that country and had only played for Romanian clubs for the past five years. But prior to that, he had spent his teenage years living in [[Basauri]] just outside Bilbao and had featured for local teams (including [[CD Basconia|Basconia]], Athletic's farm team at semi-professional level who have a separate amateur and juvenile structure), meaning he too was eligible under the 'learned skills at a Basque club' aspect of the policy.<ref name=abcficha>{{Cite news|url=http://www.abc.es/deportes/futbol/abci-athletic-ficha-ganea-primer-rumano-historia-201801151632_noticia.html|title=El Athletic ficha a Cristian Ganea, el primer rumano de su historia|trans-title=Athletic sign Cristian Ganea, the first Romanian in their history|newspaper=[[ABC (newspaper)|ABC]]|date=15 January 2018|accessdate=16 January 2018|language=Spanish}}</ref><ref name=mundoficha>{{Cite news|url=http://www.elmundo.es/deportes/futbol/2018/01/15/5a5cac83ca47419e778b4645.html|title=El Athletic ficha al internacional rumano Cristian Ganea|trans-title=Athletic sign the Romanian international Cristian Ganea|newspaper=[[El Mundo (Spain)|El Mundo]]|date=15 January 2018|accessdate=16 January 2018|language=Spanish}}</ref>
== See also == *[[Rangers F.C. signing policy]], a Scottish club who would only sign non-Catholics. *[[C.D. Guadalajara]],<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.espn.co.uk/football/guadalajara/story/3015171/matias-almeyda-enjoying-the-challenge-of-managing-chivas-all-mexican-squad|title=Matias Almeyda enjoying the challenge of managing Chivas' all-Mexican squad|language=Spanish|publisher=[[ESPN]] FC|date=8 December 2016|accessdate=11 June 2017}}</ref> a Mexican club who only field players from that nation *[[C.D. El Nacional]],<ref>{{cite web|url=https://mifutbolecuador.wordpress.com/2012/01/23/todos-las-participaciones-internacionales-de-el-nacional/|title=Todos las participaciones internacionales de El Nacional|trans-title=All the international participations of El Nacional|language=Spanish|website=El Blog de mi Futbol Ecuatoriano|date=23 January 2012|accessdate=26 December 2017}}</ref> an Ecuadorian club who only field players from that nation *[[Euskaltel–Euskadi]], defunct Basque cycling team with similar rider hiring policy

{{Refimprove|date=January 2009}}
'''Authority''' has been considered in [[Sociological theory|sociological]] terms as indicating the [[legitimacy (political)|legitimate]] or socially approved use of power. It is the legitimate power which one person or a group holds and exercises over another. The element of legitimacy is vital to the notion of authority and is the main means by which authority is distinguished from the more general concept of power. Power can be exerted by the use of force or [[violence]]. Authority, by contrast, depends on the acceptance by [[subordinate]]s of the right of those above them to give them orders or [[wiktionary:directive|directive]]s.<ref>Anthony Giddens, Sociology. London: Polity Press, 1997:581</ref><ref>Max Weber in "Weber's Rationalism and Modern Society: New Translations for the 21st Century", translated and edited by Tony Waters and Dagmar Waters. pp. 137-138.</ref>
==Types of Authorities== The types of political authority were first defined by [[Max Weber]] in his essay "[[Politics as a Vocation]]" and his other writings in 1919-1920. In this essay he emphasized that the political authority that controlled the state can be composed of the following types of authority, or what is called in German, ''Herrschaft''.<ref>Tony Waters and Dagmar Waters, Weber's Rationalism and Modern Society, Palgrave Books 2015, pp. 137-138</ref>
'''[[Traditional authority|Traditional Authority]]:''' Power legitimized by respect for long-established cultural patterns.
'''[[Charismatic authority|Charismatic Authority]]:''' Power legitimized by extraordinary personal abilities that inspire devotion and obedience.
'''[[Rational-legal authority|Rational-Legal Authority]]:''' Also known as bureaucratic authority, is when power is legitimized by legally enacted rules and regulations such as governments.
==Max Weber on authority==<!-- [[Herrschaft (sociology)]] redirects here --> {{See also|Monopoly on violence}} [[Max Weber]], in his sociological and philosophical work, identified and distinguished three types of legitimate domination (''Herrschaft'' in German, which generally means 'domination' or 'rule'), that have sometimes been rendered in English translation as types of authority, because [[Dominance (ethology)|domination]] is not seen as a political concept in the first place.{{Citation needed|date=March 2014}} Weber defined domination (authority) as the chance of commands being obeyed by a specifiable group of people. Legitimate authority is that which is recognized as legitimate and justified by both the ruler and the ruled.Legitimated rule results in what Weber called the monopoly over the use of coercive violence in a given territory.<ref>Max Weber in Weber's Rationalism and Modern Society, translated and edited by Tony Waters and Dagmar Waters, Palgrave Books 2015, pp. 136</ref> In the modern world, such authority is typically delegated to a police and court system.
Weber divided legitimate authority into three types:
*The first type discussed by Weber is ''[[rational-legal authority]]''. It is that form of authority which depends for its [[Legitimacy (political)|legitimacy]] on formal rules and established laws of the state, which are usually written down and are often very complex. The power of the rational legal authority is mentioned in the constitution. Modern societies depend on legal-rational authority. Government officials are the best example of this form of authority, which is prevalent all over the world. *The second type of authority, ''[[traditional authority]]'', derives from long-established customs, habits and social structures. When power passes from one generation to another, it is known as traditional authority. The rule of hereditary [[Monarchy|monarchs]] furnishes an obvious example. The [[Tudor dynasty]] in England and the ruling families of [[Mewar]] in [[Rajasthan]] (India) are some examples of traditional authority. * The third form of authority is ''[[charismatic authority]]''. Here, the charisma of the individual or the leader plays an important role. Charismatic authority is that authority which is derived from the leader's claims to a higher power or inspiration that is supported by his or her followers. Examples in this regard can be [[NT Rama Rao]], a matinee idol, who went on to become one of the most powerful Chief Ministers of [[Andhra Pradesh]].
History has witnessed several [[Social movement|social movements]] or [[Revolution|revolutions]] against a system of traditional or legal-rational authority started by Charismatic authorities. According to Weber, what distinguishes authority from [[coercion]], [[Force (law)|force]] and [[Coercion|power]] on the one hand, and leadership, [[persuasion]] and [[Social influence|influence]] on the other hand, is legitimacy. Superiors, he states, feel that they have a right to issue commands; subordinates perceive an obligation to obey. Social scientists{{who|date=November 2010}} agree that authority is but one of several resources available to incumbents in formal positions.{{Citation needed|date=November 2010}} For example, a Head of State is dependent upon a similar nesting of authority. His legitimacy must be acknowledged, not just by citizens, but by those who control other valued resources: his immediate staff, his cabinet, military leaders and in the long run, the administration and political apparatus of the entire society.
Authority can be created expressly when public entities act publicly, using the same means to communicate the grant of authority to their agents that they use to communicate this to third parties, apparent authority describes the situation when a principal has placed restrictions on an agent that are not known to a third party, and restrictions on government agents are accomplished in the open, through laws and regulations. In this setting, all parties concerned is assumed or supposed to know the laws and regulations of government.
Recently the concept of authority has also been discussed as a guiding principle in human–machine interaction design.<ref>Flemisch, F., Heesen, M., Hesse, T., Kelsch, J., Schieben, A., & Beller, J. (2011). [http://www.springerlink.com/content/x63032819hx560m3/ Towards a Dynamic Balance between Humans and Automation: Authority, Ability, Responsibility and Control in Cooperative Control Situations]. ''Cognition, Technology and Work''. Advance online publication. doi: 10.1007/s10111-011-0191-6</ref>
== Children and the Three Authority Attributes == Authority and its attributes have been identified as of particular relevance to children as they regard their parents and teachers. The three attributes of authority have been described as ''status'', ''specialist skills'' or ''knowledge'', and ''social position''. Children consider the type of command, the characteristics of the authority figure, and the social context when making authority conclusions.<ref>Laupa, 1991.</ref>
Although children regard these three types of authority attributes, they firstly assess the legitimacy of the authority figure in question using the nature of the commands they give. For example, a teacher that does not appear to have legitimate power from the child’s perspective (perhaps because she or he cannot control the class well) will not be obeyed. Regarding parenting, authoritative parents who are warm and high in behavioural control but low in psychological control are more likely to be seen as having legitimate authority by the child, and will believe themselves that they have a duty to obey them and internalise their values.<ref>Darling, Cumsille & Martínez, 2008.</ref>

22,000{{cite web|url=http://www.nst.com.my/latest/photographs-from-seven-locations-used-to-determine-bersih-3-0-headcount-1.86238#|title='Photographs from seven locations used to determine Bersih 3.0 headcount'|accessdate=18 June 2012|author=|date=21 May 2012|publisher=[[The Straits Times]]|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120528050412/http://www.nst.com.my/latest/photographs-from-seven-locations-used-to-determine-bersih-3-0-headcount-1.86238|archivedate=28 May 2012|df=dmy-all}}

Independent estimation:
80,000 – 100,000[http://www.aljazeera.com/news/asia-pacific/2012/04/20124286221449574.html Police violence marks Malaysia reform rally] Aljazeera. 28 April 2012.

Bersih estimation:
250,000 – 300,000 worldwide{{cite news |author=S Pathmawathy |title=300,000 at Bersih 3.0, Ambiga claims success |url=http://www.malaysiakini.com/news/196344 |accessdate=30 April 2012 |newspaper=Malaysiakini |date=28 April 2002}} | howmany2 = | howmany3 = | casualties_label = | casualties1 = 60 local demonstrators injured, 512 arrested | casualties2 = 20 policemen injured[https://web.archive.org/web/20120502191053/http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=%2F2012%2F4%2F29%2Fnation%2F11199979&sec=nation Cops release 200 protesters in batches] The Star. 29 April 2012. | casualties3 = | notes = }} The '''Bersih 3.0 rally''' (also called '''Sit In''' rally or '''Duduk Bantah''' in [[Malay language|Malay]]) was the largest democratic protest in Malaysia.http://www.malaysia-chronicle.com/index.php?option=com_k2&view=item&id=32760:malaysians-brace-for-nations-largest-ever-peoples-rally-bersih-30&Itemid=2#axzz35wvCpPqx This rally was organised as a follow-up to the [[Bersih 2.0 rally|2011 Bersih rally]] and the [[2007 Bersih rally]]. The rally, organised by the Coalition for Clean and Fair Elections ([[Bersih]]), was supported by [[Pakatan Rakyat]], the coalition of the three largest opposition parties in Malaysia along with other small political parties like [[Parti Sosialis Malaysia]] and social organisations such as [[Malaysian Trades Union Congress]], [[Human Rights Commission of Malaysia|Human Rights Commission of Malaysia (SUHAKAM)]] and [[Malaysian Bar]]. In addition, Bersih 3.0 was endorsed by 84 NGOs. In particular, it was joined by [[Himpunan Hijau]] (Green Assembly), a civil movement protesting the [[Lynas]] rare earth project in Malaysia. In addition to the main rally at Kuala Lumpur, smaller rallies were held in 10 other cities in Malaysia, as well as in 34 other countries. Following the last rally in 2011, the [[government of Malaysia]] organised a Public Select Committee (PSC) to look into electoral reforms in Malaysia, which released their proposals in April 2012. Seven of the eight demands by the Bersih have been included in the 22 recommendations submitted by the PSC. PSC Committee member [[P. Kamalanathan]] said only one demand by Bersih, on a minimum 21 days campaign period, was not included because it was not suitable to be implemented in [[Sabah]] and [[Sarawak]]. However, the matter was still being considered, where the current campaign period of seven days had been extended to 10 days.{{cite web | url=http://my.news.yahoo.com/seven-demands-bersih-included-psc-recommendations-electroral-reforms-161012891.htm| title=Seven demands by Bersih included in PSC recommendations on electoral reforms Bersih|accessdate=15 May 2012|author=|date=27 April 2012|publisher=[[Bernama]]}} Bersih claimed that PSC proposals were half-hearted and accused the [[Election Commission of Malaysia]] (EC) of being insincere in introducing electoral reforms. Bersih has stated that they would call off the rally if the Malaysian government gave a guarantee that electoral reforms take place before the next Malaysian general elections. == Background == ===Bersih=== [[File:20071110Bersih2Hafiz.jpg|thumb|300px|A scene from the 2007 rally. Protestors on the left are dressed in yellow. They are met by the [[Federal Reserve Unit]], the riot police (in red helmets). Standing in between the protestors and the riot police are PAS's Jabatan Amal volunteer unit (dressed in maroon).]] [[Bersih]], short for the Coalition for Clean and Fair Elections ({{lang-ms|Gabungan Pilihanraya '''Bersih''' dan Adil}}), is a coalition of 62 non-governmental organisations founded in November 2006.{{cite web |title=Endorsees |url=http://bersih.org/?page_id=360 |publisher=Bersih |accessdate=14 June 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120408101727/http://bersih.org/?page_id=360 |archivedate=8 April 2012 |df=dmy-all }}{{cite web |title=About BERSIH |url=http://bersih.org/?page_id=352 |publisher=Bersih |accessdate=21 June 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110622172238/http://bersih.org/?page_id=352 |archivedate=22 June 2011 |df=dmy-all }} Since its founding, Bersih has been supported by the three main opposition parties, [[Parti Keadilan Rakyat]] (PKR), PAS, and DAP. ''Bersih'' is the Malay word for "clean."{{cite web |title=Bersih |url=http://prpm.dbp.gov.my/Search.aspx?k=bersih |work=Dictionary |publisher=Dewan Bahasa dan Pustaka |accessdate=21 June 2011}} Bersih, is chaired by former [[Malaysian Bar|Bar Council]] president [[Ambiga Sreenevasan]]. Ambiga served as president of the Bar from 2007 to 2009 and is a recipient of the [[United States Department of State|US State Department]]'s International Women of Courage Awards.{{cite web |title=Presidents' Roll |url=http://www.malaysianbar.org.my/past_presidents.html |publisher=Malaysian Bar |accessdate=21 June 2011 }}{{cite web |title=Remarks by Clinton on International Women of During the lead up to the rally, it was revealed by PKR secretary-general Saifuddin Nasution Ismail in a Malay daily, that the Election Commission (EC) chairman and deputy chairman were UMNO members, leading to claims of conflict of interest. The United Malays National Organisation (abbreviated as UMNO), is Malaysia's largest political party. Bersih stated they would give the two men the benefit of the doubt until more information surfaced.[http://www.freemalaysiatoday.com/category/nation/2012/04/27/ec-umno-ties-ambiga-shocked/ EC-UMNO ties: Ambiga shocked] Free Malaysia Today[http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/ec-chief-deputy-admit-they-could-have-been-umno-members/ EC chief, deputy admit they ‘could have been’ UMNO members] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120430055002/http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/ec-chief-deputy-admit-they-could-have-been-umno-members/ |date=30 April 2012 }} The Malaysian Insider Saifuddin alleged that EC chairman, Tan Sri Abdul Aziz Mohd Yusof is a member of Bunga Daisy UMNO branch under the Putrajaya division and his deputy, Datuk Wan Ahmad Wan Omar is a member of Kubang Bunggor UMNO branch under the Pasir Mas Kelantan Division. Wan Ahmad denied the allegations and in slamming the PKR secretary-general for the "big lie", he wanted the former to apologise for slandering him. In response to the demand to step down by the opposition, EC chairman said under the Constitution, the chairman and the deputy were appointed by the [[Yang di-Pertuan Agong|King]], in line with advice from the [[Malay rulers]]. The EC Chairman stated that this was a sign of disrespect by the opposition of the royal institution.{{cite web | url=http://www.nst.com.my/nation/general/it-s-like-challenging-king-s-right-1.80167 | title='It's like challenging king's right'|accessdate=15 May 2012|author=Eileen Ng & Nancy Nais|date=3 May 2012|publisher=[[New Straits Times]]}} It turned out later that the Abdul Aziz Mohd Yusof with the details as alleged by Saifuddin is a driver at the Prime Minister's Office whose name similar to the EC chairman.{{cite web | url=http://www.sinarharian.com.my/nasional/saya-sama-nama-pengerusi-spr-1.45901 | title='Saya sama nama Pengerusi SPR'|accessdate=15 May 2012|author=|date=7 May 2012|publisher=[[Sinar Harian]]}} Then, a pensioner who runs a food stall in Kelantan, Wan Ahmad Wan Omar came forward denying the allegation and said Saifuddin had mistaken him for the EC deputy chairman. Both NRIC and Umno membership number as revealed by Saifuddin are actually belong to him.{{cite web|url=http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/litee/malaysia/article/umnos-wan-ahmad-not-ec-no.2|archive-url=https://archive.is/20130208212438/http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/litee/malaysia/article/umnos-wan-ahmad-not-ec-no.2|dead-url=yes|archive-date=8 February 2013|title=Umno's 'Wan Ahmad' not EC No.2|accessdate=15 May 2012|author=Shazwan Mustafa Kamal|date=8 May 2012|publisher=[[The Malaysian Insider]]}} UMNO Head Office also confirmed that both Tan Sri Abd Aziz and Datuk Wan Ahmad are not UMNO members.{{cite web | url=http://mstar.com.my/berita/cerita.asp?file=/2012/5/9/mstar_berita/20120509185502&sec=mstar_berita | title=Pengerusi SPR Bukan Lagi Ahli Umno – Nazri|accessdate=15 May 2012|author=|date=9 May 2012|publisher=MStar Online}} == Protest == Despite the police roadblocks, the organiser claimed up to 300,000 people turned up for the Bersih rally in and around Kuala Lumpur city centre. Close to 58 roads leading into the city were blocked by the police.[http://www.freemalaysiatoday.com/category/nation/2012/04/28/15000-at-city-centre-despite-kl-lockdown/ 80,000 at city centre despite KL lockdown] Free Malaysia Today Protestors gathered at several points in the city such as [[National Mosque of Malaysia|Masjid Negara]], Masjid India, [[Central Market, Kuala Lumpur|Pasar Seni]], [[Suria KLCC|Kuala Lumpur Convention Centre]] (KLCC), [[Brickfields]] and Jalan Sultan before proceeding to Dataran Merdeka.[http://www.freemalaysiatoday.com/category/nation/2012/04/27/court-order-and-barriers-wont-stop-bersih/ Court order and barriers won’t stop Bersih] Free Malaysia Today Police began using tear gas and water cannons to disperse the protestors therefore they began breaching the barricades.
